Whenever possible, each file is replaced by one with the extension . gz, while keeping the same ownership modes, access and modificaâ tion times. (The default extension is z for MSDOS, OS2 FAT, Windows NT FAT and Atari. ) If no files are specified, or if a file name is -, the standard input is compressed to the standard output. The gzip comâ mand will only attempt to compress regular files. In particular, it will ignore symbolic links. If the compressed file name is too long for its file system, gzip truncates it. The gzip command attempts to truncate only the parts of the file name longer than 3 characters. (A part is delimited by dots. ) If the name consists of small parts only, the longest parts are truncated. For example, if file names are limited to 14 characters, gzip. msdos. exe is compressed to gzi. msd. exe. gz. Names are not truncated on systems which do not have a limit on file name length. By default, gzip keeps the original file name and timestamp in the compressed file. These are used when decomâ pressing the file with the -N option. This is useful when the compressed file name was truncated or when the timestamp was not preserved after a file transfer. Compressed files can be restored to their original form using gzip -d or gunzip or zcat. If the original name saved in the compressed file is not suitable for its file system, a new name is constructed from the original Manual page gzip(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB one to make it legal. Manual page gzip(1) line 2 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 3 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB gunzip takes a list of files on its command line and replaces each file whose name ends with . gz, -gz, . z, -z, Manual page gzip(1) line 4 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB or _z (ignoring case) and which begins with the correct magic number with an uncompressed file without the Manual page gzip(1) line 5 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB original extension. gunzip also recognizes the special extensions . tgz and . taz as shorthands for . tar. gz and Manual page gzip(1) line 6 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB . tar. Z respectively. When compressing, gzip uses the . tgz extension if necessary instead of truncating a file Manual page gzip(1) line 7 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB with a . tar extension. Manual page gzip(1) line 8 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 9 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB gunzip can currently decompress files created by gzip, zip, compress, compress -H or pack. The detection of Manual page gzip(1) line 10 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB the input format is automatic. When using the first two formats, gunzip checks a 32 bit CRC. For pack and Manual page gzip(1) line 11 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB gunzip checks the uncompressed length. The standard compress format was not designed to allow consistency Manual page gzip(1) line 12 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB checks. However gunzip is sometimes able to detect a bad . Z file. If you get an error when uncompressing a . Z Manual page gzip(1) line 13 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB file, do not assume that the . Z file is correct simply because the standard uncompress does not complain. This Manual page gzip(1) line 14 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB generally means that the standard uncompress does not check its input, and happily generates garbage output. Manual page gzip(1) line 15 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The SCO compress -H format (lzh compression method) does not include a CRC but also allows some consistency Manual page gzip(1) line 16 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB checks. Manual page gzip(1) line 17 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 18 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Files created by zip can be uncompressed by gzip only if they have a single member compressed with the deflaâ Manual page gzip(1) line 19 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tion method. This feature is only intended to help conversion of tar. zip files to the tar. gz format. To exâ Manual page gzip(1) line 20 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tract a zip file with a single member, use a command like gunzip <foo. zip or gunzip -S . zip foo. zip. To Manual page gzip(1) line 21 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB extract zip files with several members, use unzip instead of gunzip. Manual page gzip(1) line 22 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 23 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The zcat command is identical to gunzip -c. (On some systems, zcat may be installed as gzcat to preserve the Manual page gzip(1) line 24 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB original link to compress. ) zcat uncompresses either a list of files on the command line or its standard inâ Manual page gzip(1) line 25 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB put and writes the uncompressed data on standard output. zcat will uncompress files that have the correct Manual page gzip(1) line 26 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB magic number whether they have a . gz suffix or not. Manual page gzip(1) line 27 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 28 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The gzip command uses the Lempel-Ziv algorithm used in zip and PKZIP. The amount of compression obtained deâ Manual page gzip(1) line 29 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB pends on the size of the input and the distribution of common substrings. Typically, text such as source code Manual page gzip(1) line 30 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB or English is reduced by 60-70. Compression is generally much better than that achieved by LZW (as used in Manual page gzip(1) line 31 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB compress), Huffman coding (as used in pack), or adaptive Huffman coding (compact). Manual page gzip(1) line 32 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page gzip(1) line 33 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Compression is always performed, even if the compressed file is slightly larger than the original. Whenever possible, each file is replaced by one with the extension . gz, while keeping the same ownership modes, access and modificaâ tion times. (The default extension is z for MSDOS, OS2 FAT, Windows NT FAT and Atari. ) If no files are specified, or if a file name is -, the standard input is compressed to the standard output. The gzip comâ mand will only attempt to compress regular files. In particular, it will ignore symbolic links. If the compressed file name is too long for its file system, gzip truncates it. The gzip command attempts to truncate only the parts of the file name longer than 3 characters. (A part is delimited by dots. ) If the name consists of small parts only, the longest parts are truncated. For example, if file names are limited to 14 characters, gzip. msdos. exe is compressed to gzi. msd. exe. gz. Names are not truncated on systems which do not have a limit on file name length. By default, gzip keeps the original file name and timestamp in the compressed file. These are used when decomâ pressing the file with the -N option. This is useful when the compressed file name was truncated or when the timestamp was not preserved after a file transfer. Compressed files can be restored to their original form using gzip -d or gunzip or zcat. If the original name saved in the compressed file is not suitable for its file system, a new name is constructed from the original Manual page zcat(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit) one to make it legal. Manual page zcat(1) line 2 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 3 (press h for help or q to quit) gunzip takes a list of files on its command line and replaces each file whose name ends with . gz, -gz, . z, -z, Manual page zcat(1) line 4 (press h for help or q to quit) or _z (ignoring case) and which begins with the correct magic number with an uncompressed file without the Manual page zcat(1) line 5 (press h for help or q to quit) original extension. gunzip also recognizes the special extensions . tgz and . taz as shorthands for . tar. gz and Manual page zcat(1) line 6 (press h for help or q to quit) . tar. Z respectively. When compressing, gzip uses the . tgz extension if necessary instead of truncating a file Manual page zcat(1) line 7 (press h for help or q to quit) with a . tar extension. Manual page zcat(1) line 8 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 9 (press h for help or q to quit) gunzip can currently decompress files created by gzip, zip, compress, compress -H or pack. The detection of Manual page zcat(1) line 10 (press h for help or q to quit) the input format is automatic. When using the first two formats, gunzip checks a 32 bit CRC. For pack and Manual page zcat(1) line 11 (press h for help or q to quit) gunzip checks the uncompressed length. The standard compress format was not designed to allow consistency Manual page zcat(1) line 12 (press h for help or q to quit) checks. However gunzip is sometimes able to detect a bad . Z file. If you get an error when uncompressing a . Z Manual page zcat(1) line 13 (press h for help or q to quit) file, do not assume that the . Z file is correct simply because the standard uncompress does not complain. This Manual page zcat(1) line 14 (press h for help or q to quit) generally means that the standard uncompress does not check its input, and happily generates garbage output. Manual page zcat(1) line 15 (press h for help or q to quit) The SCO compress -H format (lzh compression method) does not include a CRC but also allows some consistency Manual page zcat(1) line 16 (press h for help or q to quit) checks. Manual page zcat(1) line 17 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 18 (press h for help or q to quit) Files created by zip can be uncompressed by gzip only if they have a single member compressed with the deflaâ Manual page zcat(1) line 19 (press h for help or q to quit) tion method. This feature is only intended to help conversion of tar. zip files to the tar. gz format. To exâ Manual page zcat(1) line 20 (press h for help or q to quit) tract a zip file with a single member, use a command like gunzip <foo. zip or gunzip -S . zip foo. zip. To Manual page zcat(1) line 21 (press h for help or q to quit) extract zip files with several members, use unzip instead of gunzip. Manual page zcat(1) line 22 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 23 (press h for help or q to quit) The zcat command is identical to gunzip -c. (On some systems, zcat may be installed as gzcat to preserve the Manual page zcat(1) line 24 (press h for help or q to quit) original link to compress. ) zcat uncompresses either a list of files on the command line or its standard inâ Manual page zcat(1) line 25 (press h for help or q to quit) put and writes the uncompressed data on standard output. zcat will uncompress files that have the correct Manual page zcat(1) line 26 (press h for help or q to quit) magic number whether they have a . gz suffix or not. Manual page zcat(1) line 27 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 28 (press h for help or q to quit) The gzip command uses the Lempel-Ziv algorithm used in zip and PKZIP. The amount of compression obtained deâ Manual page zcat(1) line 29 (press h for help or q to quit) pends on the size of the input and the distribution of common substrings. Typically, text such as source code Manual page zcat(1) line 30 (press h for help or q to quit) or English is reduced by 60-70. Compression is generally much better than that achieved by LZW (as used in Manual page zcat(1) line 31 (press h for help or q to quit) compress), Huffman coding (as used in pack), or adaptive Huffman coding (compact). Manual page zcat(1) line 32 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 33 (press h for help or q to quit) Compression is always performed, even if the compressed file is slightly larger than the original. The worst Manual page zcat(1) line 34 (press h for help or q to quit) case expansion is a few bytes for the gzip file header, plus 5 bytes per 32 KiB block, or an expansion ratio Manual page zcat(1) line 35 (press h for help or q to quit) of 0. 015 for large files. The actual number of used disk blocks almost never increases. Manual page zcat(1) line 36 (press h for help or q to quit) Manual page zcat(1) line 37 (press h for help or q to quit) gzip normally preserves the mode and modification timestamp of a file when compressing or decompressing. If Manual page zcat(1) line 38 (press h for help or q to quit) you have appropriate privileges, it also preserves the files owner and group. This option is supported only on some Manual page zcat(1) line 43 (press h for help or q to quit) non-Unix systems. For MSDOS, CR LF is converted to LF when compressing, and LF is converted to CR LF Manual page zcat(1) line 44 (press h for help or q to quit) when decompressing. Manual page tar(1) line 30 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 31 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBBDESCRIPTION Manual page tar(1) line 32 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB GNU tar is an archiving program designed to store multiple files in a single file (an archive), and to manipuâ Manual page tar(1) line 33 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB late such archives. The archive can be either a regular file or a device (e. g. a tape drive, hence the name Manual page tar(1) line 34 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB of the program, which stands for tape archiver), which can be located either on the local or on a remote maâ Manual page tar(1) line 35 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB chine. Manual page tar(1) line 36 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 37 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Option styles Manual page tar(1) line 38 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Options to GNU tar can be given in three different styles. In traditional style, the first argument is a Manual page tar(1) line 39 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB cluster of option letters and all subsequent arguments supply arguments to those options that require them. Manual page tar(1) line 40 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The arguments are read in the same order as the option letters. Any command line words that remain after all Manual page tar(1) line 41 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB options have been processed are treated as non-option arguments file or archive member names. Manual page tar(1) line 42 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 43 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB For example, the c option requires creating the archive, the v option requests the verbose operation, and the Manual page tar(1) line 44 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB f option takes an argument that sets the name of the archive to operate upon. The following command, written Manual page tar(1) line 45 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB in the traditional style, instructs tar to store all files from the directory etc into the archive file Manual page tar(1) line 46 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB etc. tar, verbosely listing the files being archived Manual page tar(1) line 47 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 48 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tar cfv etc. tar etc Manual page tar(1) line 49 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 50 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB In UNIX or short-option style, each option letter is prefixed with a single dash, as in other command line Manual page tar(1) line 51 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB utilities. If an option takes an argument, the argument follows it, either as a separate command line word, Manual page tar(1) line 52 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB or immediately following the option. However, if the option takes an optional argument, the argument must Manual page tar(1) line 53 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB follow the option letter without any intervening whitespace, as in -gtmpsnar. db. Manual page tar(1) line 54 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 55 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Any number of options not taking arguments can be clustered together after a single dash, e. g. -vkp. An opâ Manual page tar(1) line 56 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tion that takes an argument (whether mandatory or optional) can appear at the end of such a cluster, e. g. Manual page tar(1) line 57 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB -vkpf a. tar. Manual page tar(1) line 58 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 59 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The example command above written in the short-option style could look like Manual page tar(1) line 60 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 61 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tar -cvf etc. tar etc Manual page tar(1) line 62 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB or Manual page tar(1) line 63 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tar -c -v -f etc. tar etc Manual page tar(1) line 64 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 65 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB In GNU or long-option style, each option begins with two dashes and has a meaningful name, consisting of Manual page tar(1) line 66 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB lower-case letters and dashes. When used, the long option can be abbreviated to its initial letters, provided Manual page tar(1) line 67 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB that this does not create ambiguity. Arguments to long options are supplied either as a separate command line Manual page tar(1) line 68 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB word, immediately following the option, or separated from the option by an equals sign with no intervening Manual page tar(1) line 69 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB whitespace. Optional arguments must always use the latter method. Manual page tar(1) line 70 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 71 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Here are several ways of writing the example command in this style Manual page tar(1) line 72 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 73 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tar --create --file etc. tar --verbose etc Manual page tar(1) line 74 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB or (abbreviating some options) Manual page tar(1) line 75 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB tar --cre --fileetc. tar --verb etc Manual page tar(1) line 76 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB Manual page tar(1) line 77 (press h for help or q to quit) ESCESCOOBB The options in all three styles can be intermixed, although doing so with old options is not encouraged.
